segments.text: And he presented, and the staff said, well, Colonel, that sounds pretty good.
I would go along with it.
I wouldn't fight it, because even though I may not like it, it wasn't my idea.
That doesn't mean that I shouldn't accept it.
And I said, whatever's good for the unit, let's go with it.
In other words, as far as leadership was concerned, what you feel is one of your assets is flexibility.
Would you say that?
I would say that wholeheartedly.
I was flexible in mine.
I know I'm not the smartest man in the world, I know that.
And yet I could, I feel I was astute in gleaming somebody's ideas and using them.
And that helped me along the way.
Yeah, we all need excellent subordinates.
Oh, yeah.
If you don't have them, you can't make them.
I don't know, I like these, even in civilian life, these corporations stuff, you know.

those companies that failed is because friends were in there and positioned and family you know and trying to run a corporation didn't have the great matter to do it let's continue now with 1964 let's continue with your career in the reserves what happened after well in 1964 command the second brigade 90th infantry infantry
And did you get a promotion along with that?
I got a promotion along with that.
I was a lieutenant colonel.
And General Travis, Bob Travis of San Antonio, was a commanding general.
And he recommended to 4th Army at the time that I take over the infantry brigade in Houston.
And there was a lot of resistance to it.
Why?
Because I was a lieutenant colonel.
They said they had colonels in the area who they felt should take over the job.
But General Travis insisted and stuck to his guns.
He said, well, what good did it do Kokonos to do such a superior job as a battalion commander if I can't promote him?
And so finally they did.
remaining general of the Fifth Army, he said, okay.
And so they put me in that job, and General Travis called me to Austin, Texas, the headquarters, and pinned my eagles on me.
Oh, yeah, it was a great thrill.
It really was.
That was a big step.
Almost as big as from Colonel to General.
It really was a big step.
And so I took over the infantry brigade, and I walked into a harness nest.
Tell me about that brigade.
no sense mentioning the former commander's name.
And he was an Aggie.
No kidding?
And the place was a mess?
Well, the staff was a mess.
He liked certain type of people.
And when I walked in there, I could sense that my executive officer was just not on the team.
And he was, you know, I could see that he was
upset because he didn't get the command, and he was upset because the old commander was gone, and I was a new commander coming in.
And I sensed it immediately.
What rank was he?
Lieutenant Colonel.
And I was Lieutenant Colonel.
So after the second- Was he senior in time?
No, I was senior.
And after the second meeting, I called him in and told him to find another job.
Really?
Yes.
What did he say to that?
He said, you can't do that to me.
I said, yes, I can.
I said, yes, I can.
I command this unit, and I'm the commander, and you go find you another home somewhere else.
No kidding.
And don't show up the next meeting.
He said, you can't do that.
You have to go through the Army Reserve Command and through Army.
I said, I'm telling you to find you another home.
You're not fit to be the executive officer of this regiment or brigade.
So...
Did he show up next time?
He did not show up.
Well, in the meantime, I called General Travis, told him what I was doing.
General Travis concurred.
He says, you're the brigade commander, and you do what you want to down there, and I'll support you 100%.
How can you beat that?
That's right.
It really makes you feel good when you've got a commander behind you.
And I learned that.
And so that's what I did to my men.
And so I pulled a major up, Major Bill Nieder.
He was the adjutant.
And I pulled him up.
At meetings, I just looked at staff over and evaluated them.
And I got my feeling.
I could feel who I wanted to be my key staff people.
And so I asked Major Nieder.
I called him in.
I says, Major Nieder, you're my executive officer, and I'm going to promote you lieutenant colonel.
He says, over all these other people?
I says, Major Nieder.
I said, you're going to be my exec officer.
You want the job?
Yes, sir.
OK. Well, Bill and I became very dear friends.
And he did a tremendous job for me.
I got some criticism from the former commander for me selecting Nader.
When I got that, I knew I'd selected the right man.
I see.
And so anyway, we worked together.
We revamped the staff.
So that was the first major problem.
That was my first major problem.
And the unit, the disciplinary, the discipline wasn't so good.
But after several meetings where they perked up, men knew I meant business.
It was strictly business.
And I began to visit the staff members to see just, you know, what was going on and everything.
In fact, one of the staff members was a county judge down in
Near Eagle Lake.
I think he's a federal judge now.
Really?
Yeah.
And I had a, one of my battalion commanders was an internal revenue man.
Shawrock, Jim Shawrock.
And let me say something else.
You know him.
He's at A&M, Jim Bradley.
I've heard of him.
You heard him.
He's in the economic development, Dr. Bradley.
Jim Bradley was a lieutenant colonel.

and Brian he had a battalion down there this infantry battalion and he was my senior and when he wasn't selected oh he was the acting brigade regiment brigade commander until I got selected and the minute I got selected Jim came and I knew Jim and he knew me from training and everything from school

came to me and he says, Colonel Coconose, and we knew each other by first name, Jim or Mike, you know, he didn't call me Mike, he says, Colonel Coconose, he says, you're my commanding officer and whatever you want me to do, I'm willing to do it.
And he says, you want me to step aside and let somebody else take this battalion, I'd be glad to do it.
He says, whatever you want to do, it's up to you.
And I looked at him, and I says, Jim, I want you to be the battalion commander.
And he shook my hand.
We shook hands, and it was the greatest friendship I can enjoy, and I still enjoy it today with Jim Bradley.
That's great.
It really is.
Because he was senior, and he was expected to be named the commander, and he wasn't.
Because he'd been in that regiment.
Sounds like a big man, though.
Big man, really.
And he's pretty powerful.
prominent there.
He's not in the teaching anymore.
He's in the development of economic development.
And he goes to all the chamber of commerce and helps them in their city-wide.
He's been to Beaumont and helped them in their economic development.
But Jim was very gracious.
And so I kept him on.
And then I had an armored battalion.
tank commander named Leo Connor in Midland, Texas.
And he was a problem.
And I finally had to ask him to resign.
Now did you ask him to resign from the reserves or did you just tell him to resign from your staff?
I had to handle him differently.
But in general, did you have these people just resign from your staff and like you said go find some other position in the reserves someplace or did you have to try to get them out of the service?
Well, I had to treat this exec officer like this because he was
I had to hit him quick and get him out.
He had other problems that I didn't want to linger.
I didn't want him to linger.
But I went to see Colonel Connor, and he had given General Travis problems, the division commander.
So I had to handle him a little different.
And I went to him and said, now, Leo, you have to just, we just have to get another commander down here.
You flunked the IG for several, couple of times, and inspections are bad, and you're treating the division staff like dirt.
I said, we can't have that.
So he said, Mike, you're right.
I'll do it.
And so we.
He was.
So he retired from the service?
Well, no, he went to another unit.
And everything began to straighten out down there.
I'd fly to Midland and see him and visit with him until we got this thing all straightened out.
And I want to ask you a question about General Travis.
With all of these people who could have taken over, why do you think he picked you?
Why do you have so much confidence in you?
Of course, General Kidwell, who was my Daivari commander, who I worked for, went to bat for him, would tell him, says, Colonel Coker knows who's getting all these superiors on the,
on the firing range and who's getting these superiors on maneuvers, RSOP, constant selection occupation position.
He's getting our superiors.
He's the one that's really doing a great job for division artillery and deserves a promotion.
And Travis began to watch me.
I knew that.
I knew he'd come to the field.
And I knew he was evaluating me.
But it didn't make any difference.
I never put on a show for anybody.
I always had a show going, don't get me wrong.
Right, it was your own.
Yeah, it was my own, that's right.
That's somebody else's.
We were spitting polish in the field.
I met them all shave every day, bathe every day.
We'd go out to the field for four or five days at a time.
I met them all, put on new tees every day.
And I would see that they were laundered and back so they could change.
And hot meals in the field.
possible.
Oh yeah.
So in other words you tried to treat your men as well as possible.
Oh, listen, I always did.
Your idea was they'll treat you the same way.
So General Kidwell really led the fight with Travis to get me to take over that.
General Travis, you know, he felt strongly about it that he
Stood his ground.
Yeah, you're right.
I guess you're right.
Terry felt I could get the job done.
Because the track record was good.
OK, now let's go to the next.
After the command of that brigade, then what?
What was the next move?
Go.
That was tragic.
McNamara became Secretary of Defense, and he eliminated the combat arms and the reserve program.
Oh, really?
Oh, yeah.
All the divisions, all the United States.
That was tragic.
So what happened to you?
Well, now let me tell you.
So this is 1966 then?
Right.
General is probably going to the 75th Maneuver Area Command.
Yeah, I know this, but I don't understand what that means.
Okay.
The order came out.
that the original order came out that the National Guard would be dissolved and put into their army reserve.
It would be one army reserve.
And politics took over real strong.
The governors really got hot.
Because the National Guard are governor troops.
And they're not federal troops like the reserve.
Even in the armor drilling, they're state troopers until they're called up by the Secretary of Defense or Secretary of the Army.
Then they're federal troops.
Even in summer training, they're not federal troops.
They're still guards, state guards.
But anyway, the guard fought it, fought it, fought it, and McNamara reversed himself completely.
He says, okay, we'll put these.
Army Reserve combat arms, infantry, artillery, armored, and combat engineers into the Guard.
So we fought it too.
But we were under the command of the Secretary of Defense.
So we couldn't do any political action at all, you know.
He was our commander, actually, Secretary of Defense under the President.
And President Johnson was
was the president then, Lyndon Johnson.
And he went along with McNamara.
It was a big mistake.
Really, it was a trap.
Because the quality of personnel in the Army Reserve was head and shoulder above anything in the National Guard, especially the combat arms.
And here we had eight divisions in the United States, highly trained.
In the 9th Division, Texas, we had close to 9,000 people, which was almost 100% strength for a division.
Highly trained.
Combat veterans, either the World War II or Korea, and here he is dissolving them, getting rid of them.
Well, we got the order, no more 9th Division.
And so then General Travis called a division commander's meeting
and bring your staff, so we brought our staffs to Austin.
And he said that he was going to continue the 9th Division on a non-pay status.
What does that mean?
Means we would continue to drill at the Armory under our old unit designation, like the 2nd Brigade of the 90th, and that we would not get paid
We didn't know if we could go to summer training camp or not.
What they call a non-pay status unit.
And so he wanted to know how many of us would go along with him.
Figuring that if we did that, then maybe McNamara would see our desire and our dedication to the Army Reserve and that he would change his mind.
And he didn't continue if he didn't.
So we, 100%.
Really?
We all said, yes, we'd stay with you.
Well, after a month or so, Travis, General Travis found out it was fruitless to, useless to even continue that way because we weren't getting the support of the Department of the Army.
McNamara wasn't going to change his mind.
And the Department of the Army was going to pull in our flags and guide-ons and take away our equipment.
And it would just be a little stag meeting.
And so...
Travis says, okay.
He calls us back in again.
He says, where are they going to assign you to the National Guard units?
So if you don't like your assignment and you want to continue, well, come back to Austin and we'll organize our own non-unit headquarters.
Well, my brigade people in Houston got assigned to the 75th Maneuver Area Command.
75th Maneuver Area Command.
Which is part of the National Guard.
No, no.
Okay, let me explain that to you.
We had a choice.
We had a choice to go to the Guard, 36th Division, or to any reserve unit that we could find a home.
Oh, I see.
See?
So we had to seek our own home if we didn't want to go to the Guard.
So you found the 75th Maneuver Area Command.

command, and this is what took you out of the artillery, basically, and then you're in this petroleum intersection, which I have no idea what that is, which seems quite different from anything you've done, and I could not figure that out when I was reading through this.
We'll take that step by step.
We got assigned, we asked to be assigned, my brigade people, we had to take inventory or counter.
How many wanted to go to the guard?
Nobody.
None of my officers.
Nobody.
Nobody wanted to go to the guard.
How many officers were there in general, approximately?
Thirty-some-odd officers on my staff.
Oh, yeah.
Oh, yeah.
Not a single one of them wanted to go to the guard.
Because you considered it that inferior.
That's right.
Now, a couple of the enlisted men went to the guard because they got promoted.
They told the enlisted men,
If he was a buck sergeant, they'd promote him to a four-striper or a five-striper.
So several of the enlisted men, which was fine.
They went to the Guard.
But not a single man went to the National Guard.
And so I said, okay, we'll all go.
I'll go see General Davis.
He was the commander of the 75th New Area Command.
Felix Davis.
He was the commander.
And where was the 75th?
In the armory at the Old Spaniards Trail in Houston.
Okay, that was headquarters.
Headquarters.
The 75th Maneuver Every Command is a command post type exercise headquarters.
They put on exercises, map maneuvers, command post exercise, and field exercises.
And they go out and umpire.
Oh, so they're sort of umpires.
They're umpires.
Exactly.
They're umpires.
And so we went to that unit.
Now, how did you get in?
Weren't they filled?
They were filled.
But Department of the Army said they could take us all in as excess.
In other words, the Department of the Army sort of got around McNamara.
They sure did.
And said you can go to the 75th as excess office for one year.
And after that one year, you had to find your slot to get into.
a position.
So we all went over there and General Davis, shall I mention names?
Okay, General Davis assigned everybody a slot except Colonel Nieder and I.
In the meantime, Major Nieder became a colonel and we became dear friends.
But prior to assignment, he called me in
And he says, now, you know these people, where should they be assigned?
And I did.
I went down the staff roster, and I said, put Robinson in the aviation, put in the training area.
And he said, well, don't worry about .
And then we went on down the line.
And so when we got through, he said, well, Colonel ,, I don't know where we're going to assign you.
We don't have a spot for you.
I said, all right, how about Colonel Eater?
Well, we don't have a spot for him either.
So I said, okay, that's fine.
You said, would you like to stay in the unit?
I said, sure, we'll stay as excess.
It wasn't a friendly meeting.
No, it doesn't sound like friendly.
No.
It sounded like he was very jealous, isn't it?
Very jealous.
He was jealous of the 9th Division.
And we had a run-in.
Because you did such a good job before?
Well, my reputation did perceive me
But we sat on the armory council together.
And General Davis was chairman of the armory council.
And the army council composed of the commanders in the building.
He commanded one unit.
I commanded the brigade headquarters.
And also there was an infantry battalion in there.
And then there was a medical commander.
And then there was a transportation commander.
And there was one of those five commanders.
sent on the council.
And they ran the armory.
They allocated the spaces.
And they determined which offices would be open.
He wanted all his offices closed that his people trained in, and nobody could use them.
Well, if we did that, we wouldn't have an armory to train in, see?
And we tried to tell him that.
He says, you've got to leave your office open.
You can't do it.
He says, I won't do it.
See, like these offices here.
Well, a commander, we said we'd have a common office for a commander.
And since you're a general officer, we will give you a desk.
You lock your desk, put all your papers in, and we won't touch it.
We'll bring our files in.
He didn't want that.
He wanted his own general office.
And I can understand.
But he wanted to give all his key staff people offices.
and locked the door.
Well, we just didn't have that kind of room.
If you could see the building, Terry.
Oh, no, we didn't have it.
It was an old, antiquated building built back in 1930 or something.
And he didn't want to share it.
He didn't want to share it.
He was very selfish.
So we resisted it, and I voted him.
And we sent it to the Army commander in the Fifth or Fourth Army.
What do you mean you voted him?
We had a vote.
What we would do with the offices.
Because he voted to close the office, and we all, four to one, voted to open them.
And he didn't accept that majority.
And he came to me after the meeting, and he says, you led this revolt against me, and I'm going to hold it against you.
I said, General Davis, sir, no, sir.
I'm not revolting against you.
I just don't think it's fair.
Well, I'm pointing this finger at you.
And he used some profanity, and I maintained my composure, and I said, no, sir.
I said, we just feel like it's fair that we leave the office open.
So by the time then that you went down to the 75th maneuver, the stage was already set, so to speak.
Set, right.
And I said, this happened about a year and a half, two years before I got there.
So when I got there, he didn't have a spot for me.
And I said, that's fine.
What you probably knew was.
Well, that he was upset with me.
So I said, that's all right.
And so what did you do for the next year then?
So I trained with him.
I stayed with him.
I said, well, now, can I train with you?
Sure.
He says, I'm going to assign you to the S3 section.
Colonel Hayden, full colonel.
But then he said he didn't have a... Well, he didn't have a...
I was over.
I was at surplus.
See, remember, for a year, we could stay one year at surplus.
Okay.
At surplus.
Well, we start meeting...
That's when they started weekend trainings then.
We used to meet once a week until they would start weekend training.
So the first meeting I went in, Carlos Hayden was my, he was the operation officer, and he was a full colonel, I was a full colonel.
And he operated me maybe a couple of years.
But it didn't really mean much.
I mean, you could be full colonels, but really rank doesn't mean that much.
But I'll tell you, Terry, great.
My combat record, no one could question it.
And that just stood before him all the time.
The Silver Star, the Purple Heart, the three combat stars, the European, and that in the group, it was a great plus for me.
Yeah.
And then, this unit was kind of a sloppy unit.
The dress wasn't so good, and some come unshaved, wasn't shaved.
I come in, I was sparkle, what am I telling you?
And I purposely made it that way, that I would shine my boots longer and louder and shinier so they would look better, and my fatigues were
heavily starched.
You could sit them in the corner, they were so starched.
Oh, yeah.
And my weight was down, and I was trim.
And I just kept my military bearing, and I knew I had to.
This is one time, early in the conversation, I mentioned that, you know, there were some prejudices.
After the second or third meeting, Carlos Hayden was turning to me to tell him what to do.
Really?
Right.
How to run an Infra Brigade field exercise.
The National Guard had asked us to put on a field exercise for the 36th Division at Fort Hood for the summer.
And they wanted a retrograde movement and also a river crossing.
And he asked me to set the plan up.
And I did.
I got Major Eater.
He just wasn't capable of doing it.
Well, he just...
He knew you could do a better job.
Yes, so I went and got Colonel Eater.
He said, get you three or four officers and work this plan.
I got Colonel Eater and I got Edwards, my other officer, and we sat down and we worked the plan out.
He took it in the colonel to General Davis.
And I have to admit, General Davis called me in and he congratulated me.
He says, I got a job for you now.
I'm going to make you the plans officer.
This was after about the...
So your year wasn't up yet?
No, this was about my second or third month.
So it was a stormy beginning, but then they could see your usefulness.
That's right.
I could be used.
And so he made me the plan officer.
Oh, good.
So I made all the plans for the 75th Maneuver Air Commandment.
And it's like Operation Officer, but I was under the Operation Officer, but I was his planner.
And so from that day on, General Davis...
asked me to do the briefings at Army headquarters.
I would go to the Army commander and had to present them the plans of what we were going to do for 36th Division or the 49th Armored Division.
And General Davis asked me to present the plan operation of the whole thing, and I would be the briefing officer at the Army.
You did have a lot of responsibility there.
Oh, gosh.
In fact, we

He would take the whole staff with him, about 15, 20 officers, and there were colonels and lieutenant colonels, and there were three generals, General Davis, General Frazier, and General, oh, I forgot his name.
Anyway, they would all go to the briefing, and we'd go to Fort Sam Houston, say a Thursday night, and we'd brief Friday morning, and they liked to party.
And I wouldn't party.
I mean, I'd be in a party, but I'd drink water, because I didn't want to.
I knew what I had to do the next morning, and General Davis said, what's the matter, you don't drink?
I said, yes sir, I drink.
I drink just as much as you or anybody else, but I got a job to do in the morning, I want to be clear.
Well, it partied all night long at the VIP headquarters, I mean, B.O.Q.
Hell, next morning I was up bright and early, got all my damn slides ready, and I got my briefing notes, and
And hell, I'd run a mile or two before everybody else that got up.
And so at the briefing, man, hell, I hit the Army commander three-star general right in the eye with our briefing.
Anyway, I did him a good job.
And he liked it.
Made him look good.
Made him look damn good.
I wrote some operations in China.
wrote a plan of a field exercise in Cambodia before the Vietnam War.
It's still in their files.
How to maneuver tanks in Cambodia.
And I was briefing the army commander on this Cambodia exercise, and I threw in two armored divisions, and his operation, Colonel Abush,
was the regular army operation officer.
He jumped straight up in there and says, you can't use tanks in Cambodia.
And I says, well, Colonel Abish, we certainly can't.
Never.
No one has ever put tanks in Cambodia.
Why aren't you realistic about this?
Don't be hypothetical in saying you can.
In front of the commander, in front of the guard, General Bishop was there, the action general.
And so I said, well, Colonel Abish, I'll tell you what we did.

We went to Fort Knox, Kentucky, and we presented this plan, before we presented it to you here today, and presented it to the armored people and see if they could put armor to camera, and they said they could do it 100%.
Now, if the armored people say they can do it, how come you say they can't?
You didn't have much to say there.
No, he did.
He sat down.
He sat down.
He says, well, and then later he come along and said, Mike, you really got me, didn't you?
I said, well, I didn't mean to.
You know, you jumped straight up in the air, and you were about to jump down my throat.
But anyway, General Davis was delighted and pleased, and when I left the 75th Maneuver Area Command to take over a group, the 173rd Combat Support Group.
And what year was that?
And organized in Beaumont.
This group...
What did you do there?
I was still a full colonel.
Did Davis get this job for you?
No, oh no.
He didn't want me to leave then.
You were too valuable then.
He really didn't want me to leave.
He was very nice.
You were ready for your own command.
I really was and I always liked the command.
I was staff then, and so the general out of New Orleans, Louisiana, my dad, he asked me to take over this group.
It was a new group.
Never had been in existence before, and it was being organized in Beaumont.
He wondered if I'd take it.
I said, sure.
So I took this group.
And got the same people that was in the artillery battalion.
In the meantime, the artillery battalion had become a service supply battalion.
So I took those people and we were reorganizing into a direct support group.
So you got your old subordinates.
Subordinates, right.
They're really good ones, John.
Right.
Got them all back.
Those of them who were still left there.
Some of them quit because they didn't want to be in a supply unit, the artillery people.
And I was
I commanded that group for two years as full colonel.
And what were your jobs?
What was your function and duty there?
Why did you have this?
Why did they set this up, the 173rd to begin with?
Why did we need it?
It was a service supply unit type thing.
We had laundry units, we had shower bath units, graze registration, these services that support logistically.
We had logistics.

A new command for me, but I felt I could handle it without any problem, because the experience I had in the brigade and the experience I had in the 75th Maneuver Air Command, I didn't feel the supply service type organization would give me any trouble at all, which they did.
And then I had one incident.
I had a unit in Bogalusa, Louisiana.
It was a shower unit.
And the captain of that unit was Captain Beauregard, like Beauregard Parish.
And in fact, he's related to them.
OK, he had some blacks in his unit.
And he also had some Ku Klux Klansmen in his units.
And so I didn't know all of this.
We were at Fort Polk, Louisiana.
So I invited the general, uh, commanding general of Fort Polk to come down and see the first, to witness the opening of our shower unit.
Now this Captain Beauregard set up the shower unit.
And so, uh, and I suggested to him that he formed the company out there and have them all take showers.
while the commanding officer, commanding general, would watch it and whatever his staff.
So Beauregard thought it was a great idea.
So sure enough, here comes all the dignitaries.
And I noticed that there was some flurry of activity on my staff.
They were talking.
So I called Colonel Bell over.
I said, Colonel Bell, what's the problem?
He says, well,
We're about to have a revolt in Beauregard's company because the white boys don't want to take a shower with the black boys.
I said, oh.
What are they going to do?
They said, well, they're going to walk away.
I said, oh, god, that's not good, is it?
No.
I said, OK, line them up.
So they lined them all up.
And the water's ready to pour, and the shower's off.
So Captain Beauregard saw me coming.
with the staff, the VIPs, and we got up there and we saluted.
I said, Captain Beauregard, I want you, me, I said, I want you and me, and I want this man, this man, this man, this man.
I picked out three whites and three blacks to take showers with me, and I started taking off my clothes.
And when the white boys saw me taking off my clothes, they all started taking off their clothes.
And so the black boys, they just went ahead and took the clothes.
So we all took showers together.
From then on, we had no more problems.
That's a really intelligent way to resolve that.
I thought that.
I thought so.
Did you think of that when you were walking out there?
Well, after Captain Bell told me this, I began to think.
And I said, you've got to do something.
And I said, hell, I'll just take the bulls by the horn.
Really?
And I'll just take my clothes off and take a shower with them.
And so we took a shower together, and after that, we had no more problems.
Captain Beauregard came to me later, and he says, how did you know about what was going on?
I said, well, I heard.
And he said, well, I've been having a lot of trouble ever since I've been in camp.
I said, well, why don't you tell me about this thing?
He said, I don't think you'll have any more trouble.
He said, I don't think I will either, because the guys that I picked were Klansmen.
And they weren't going to tell on each other.
See, what they were afraid of, they'd go back home to Boogaloosa, Louisiana, and they would say, hey, you took a bath with a black guy.
And since I stepped in there and said, you come with me and take a shower, well, that made it OK, because they would use me as an excuse.
So that kind of prevented a little racial incident there.
Well, during this whole time, did you have any problems with the racial incidents?
Not really.
No problem.
Because the South was really going under a transition.
Yeah.
from the 50s to the 60s and into the 70s, and at the same time you were commanding units.
When did your units start taking blacks?
Gee, I can't remember the date we started taking blacks.
Did you back in?
Actually, we were taking blacks all the time.
Few, not many.
And they were key, and they were good, and uh, they were just a few.
And uh, uh,
But I never had any trouble with blacks.
I never had trouble with any of them, really, to tell you the truth.
Did any of the units have trouble besides this one?
Not that I can remember.
None of my units ever had any trouble.
Even when we went to Fort Chaffee, we never had any trouble.
Why do you think you didn't have trouble?
Because the rest of the society seemed to be having trouble at that time, in the mid-1960s.
Well, because I guess I'm related to them.
You know, I'd go to the black, and I'd shake his hand, put my arm around his shoulder,
doing a good job, keep it up, you know.
And the white soldier would see me and say, hell, the commander's doing it, what can I do?
You know, be friendly with him.
And so, and I looked after him.
I made sure everybody was fed and good and had good barracks.
It took me to Fort Hood one day and I had a,
My unit, this direct support unit, sent me to Fort Hood for training.
And they put us in tents on South Fort Hood next to some beautiful army barracks that were empty.
And so the advance party went there.
And so when I got there, Colonel Bell says, Colonel, we're going to sleep in tents.
I said, what's that over there?
He says, those are army barracks.
Let's go look at them.
Well, where are they?
Hell, they were good army barracks.
Clean, nice.
I said, why can't we live in here?
He says, we can't do it.
I said, where the hell we came?
So I went to the corps commander, three-star general named General Powell, Bev Powell, regular army corps commander.
I said, General Powell, I says, you've got some regular army barracks out there.
They're not being used.
active army barracks, and yet you put us in tents, sleeping on the dirt floor.
I said, well, come on, I'll show you.
We took a ride.
He cussed.
No, hell no.
Next thing I knew, we were in those barracks.
And so he called me in, and we became very good friends throughout the years.
And he thanked me.
You see, this is part of this.
Why was this?
Because you were a reservist?
Reservist.
This is part of what we were talking about.
Part about the active establishment resenting the reservists coming in there.
What we could do in two weeks, they couldn't do in six months, and we'd do a good job.
Of course, we had quality people, just like that architect and that engineer and controller I was telling you about.
We had tremendous people, and they could do it.
So after that, when we went back the next year, they didn't have any spaces on post, so they put us in motels.
No kidding?
Oh, yeah.
They didn't put you in tents?
They put you in a motel?
Holiday Inn.
They didn't want to go through.
They didn't want to have General Powell come.
That's a royal treatment.
That's right.
They didn't want General Powell coming down and blowing down their neck anymore.
I think he got rid of a couple of people, really.
He told me he wanted to.
And he was good to me.
He had visitors from Washington, Pentagon come visit him at home.
He invited me over for dinner a couple of times to eat with us.
It was nice.
I got along good with him.
And I would tell him about the Reserves.
And I didn't mention any words.
Down in the field, the active Army people don't help us.
I don't know.
Maybe I helped, maybe I didn't.
I don't know.
Word got back to Pentagon.
Because these were three and four star generals.
Sure.
And here I was just a colonel.
And I always maintained my position with them.
I never got smart aleck with them at all.
And, you know, they found out I played basketball at A&M.
Then they found out I was a handball champion.
In fact, General Powell lined up handball game with me.
Oh, really?
Oh, sure.
He wanted me to beat some people on the post.
He did, yeah.
And I did.
Oh, yeah.
Chaplain.
He was a colonel chaplain.
And the other guy was a...
Brigadier General, and he said, I want you to beat on him.
They think they're smart.
So I did.
I played handball.
I just beat him.
He liked that.
Anyway.
What about your last assignment then?
That's about it.
You're talking about the Quartermaster Patrol?
We've got to go there now.
Yeah, that's what I'm talking about.
That's your last assignment.
I was the commander of this direct support group in Beaumont.
I'm sitting in my office.
I went to the Army one morning, about 10.30, and the phone rings.
And it's the Army commander, the Deputy Army commander, General Franklin.
Colonel Koganos?
Yes, sir.
It's General Franklin.
Yes, sir.
You've been selected to take the Brigadier General slot in Albuquerque, New Mexico.
I said, well, what is this?
He says, there's a Brigadier General slot opening, the commander
is retired, and you have been selected to assume that position.
Would you like to have it?
That means going from Beaumont, Texas to Albuquerque, New Mexico.
I said, yes, sir.
I'd be glad to have it.
He said, OK. And you never thought about this before?
You never had any word or any hint or anything?
I knew the job was open in Mexico, but it didn't
Excite me to try to see what it was all about.
And so I went to General Frank and said, you better come see me.
We're at your convenience.
So I said, well, it'd be several days.
Of course, I was tied up in my business.
He said, well, come on up here.
And then we set a date up.
I remember it was Tuesday morning, about 10 o'clock.
So I took off for San Antonio.
And he told me, he said, now, it's a very dear General Slott.
You're a Texan.
You're going to New Mexico.
He says, I asked him the same thing, Terry.
I said, why did you select me, Joe Franklin?
He says, because you had the best record.
And you've come highly recommended to us from other sources that we sought recommendation.
Your name popped up because of your record.
And once it popped up, we began to look into it.
And we checked your background and everything.
You were the man for the job.
So I went on up there.
I flew up there on the weekend and took over command.
Next thing I knew, I was being investigated by Senator Montoya.
No kidding?
Oh, yeah.
You remember this Montoya on Watergate?
He was his ranking senior in New Mexico.
He wanted to know why a Texan would take over a New Mexico unit.
That's what his reason was.
Why was a Texan?
In other words, he wanted somebody from New Mexico to take it over.
Oh, sure.
Take it over.
and Department of the Army, and Franklin had forewarned me that they'd probably get some static.
Now, I didn't get involved with Senator Montoya myself, because he dealt with the Army.
The Army says, don't worry about it.
It says, we've got your record.
